chunk_title: Description of the Associated Loan, BH-L1041
text: This Technical Cooperation (TC) will support the implementation of the Bahamas Airport Infrastructure Program (BH-L1041; 3907/OC-BH), with the overarching goal of contributing to the regional and global sustainable integration of The Bahamas through enhancements to secure air transport infrastructure in the Family Islands (FI). The program, structured as a GOM, aims to strengthen The Bahamas’ connectivity with the Caribbean and the wider world by improving air travel efficiency and accessibility for both residents and visitors. This will be achieved through infrastructure upgrades—including the rehabilitation and maintenance of four Family Island airports (Exuma, North Eleuthera, Marsh Harbour, and Treasure Cay)—to ensure compliance with international aviation standards, with consideration for climate resilience and sustainability. This loan, of US$35,000,000 from Ordinary Capital and US$18,800,000 from the counterpart, totaling US$53,800,000, is currently active and disbursing.

3.3 Component III: Dissemination of the GCF Water Security Program in the Amazon. It is designed to strategically disseminate information about the GCF Water Security Program within high-level technical and political forums, as well as among stakeholders. This goal includes the dissemination of the Program’s Gender and Diversity Strategy, which outlines specific actions to improve access to resources and opportunities for Indigenous Peoples and Afro-descendant communities in the Amazon region.

chunk_title: Description of Activities and Outputs – Component II
text: 3.2 Component II: Promotion of the innovation agenda and fostering of alliances between actors. (i) open innovation events and calls; (ii) strengthening, exchange, and dialogue among service providers, innovators, and investors in Mexico, as well as between Mexico and other countries; (iii) dissemination and enhancement of knowledge products on innovation. Under this component, the Bank will incorporate lessons learned from relevant activities and disseminate existing knowledge products, including the participation of Japanese experts and innovative solutions.
Through enhanced dialogue, knowledge sharing, and development of tools and resources, the platform fosters cooperation among cities facing shared climate challenges.

chunk_title: Description of Activities and Outputs – Component I
text: 3.1 Component I: Knowledge Generation. It will develop a minimum of three (3) technical notes focused on Nature Based Solutions (NbS) and their application in water adaptation projects. The aim of these technical notes is to present at COP30 in Belém knowledge products that, regardless of whether they specifically focus on the Amazon, showcase advances in the application of NbS in the water sector, with the potential for scaling up.

The general objective of this Technical Cooperation (TC) is to establish the “LAC Regional Climate Change Platform for City Finance Secretaries” to support city finance secretaries in Latin America and the Caribbean (LAC) to mobilize climate financing, share knowledge, foster dialogue, and implement scalable solutions to address climate change (CC).

chunk_title: Description of Activities and Outputs – Component I
text: 3.1 Component I: Strengthening national innovation ecosystem and identification of new projects. Analyze key aspects of the ecosystem and the demand for solutions, identifying opportunities for innovation in the sector. Consulting services will be funded for (i) intelligence and diagnostics focused on strengthening innovation units; (ii) development and application of methodologies and tools; (iii) identification and introduction of solutions; and (iv) development of a study and technical note on Japan's cutting-edge solutions focused on solid waste management.

chunk_title: Data Sources, Census, and Longitudinal Design
text: 2.4 Data will come from surveys of the beneficiary households as well as from administrative data provided by multiple local government divisions. Key variables for the evaluation have been defined. The remaining details – including the timing of data collection before and after resettlement, which are essential for testing pre-trend assumptions and evaluating short- and medium-term impacts – will be defined during the drafting of the detailed evaluation plan methodology, which is also partially funded by this TC. 2.5 Data will be collected multiple times over a period of three years, starting at least 18 months before resettlement and ending 18 months afterward. The first collection will be a census, administered among all the families in the 39 communities eligible for the Program. Following IDB Safeguards standards, this census data will be used to freeze enrollment for the program, preventing the expansion of the informal settlements. The Vida Nova Project will finance this census, identifying families and their social support needs. 2.6 This TC will finance consulting services to gather the information needed for the impact evaluation, through the collection of primary data, and the identification and request of complementary administrative data. The primary data will be collected for a sample of the families eligible to receive the program. The frequency of collection and size of the sample will be defined in the detailed evaluation plan described in paragraph 2.4.

chunk_title: Description of Activities – Component IV: Dissemination Activities
text: 3.4 Component IV: This component will finance activities to disseminate findings, experiences, and products coming from this TC and CO-T17772.

VI. Project Risks and Issues. 6.1 The main risks include (i) lack of coordination among the institutions involved, particularly given the participation of both INAPA and the water utilities; and (ii) limited institutional ownership of the preparatory process. To mitigate these risks, the Bank team will organize periodic coordination meetings with the relevant government entities to ensure alignment and efficient information flow. In addition, the TC will finance components specifically aimed at strengthening institutional articulation and providing the technical support required to deliver high-quality products in a timely manner. The risk of limited institutional ownership will be mitigated by ensuring the direct participation of technical counterparts from the sector institutions in the preparation of the investment plans.

2.1 The main objective of this Technical Cooperation (TC) is to develop a sustainable technical and financial mechanism for the restoration, conservation, and monitoring of coral reefs in the Dominican Republic. This mechanism will integrate activities such as awareness campaigns, technical analysis, financing strategy design, pilot tests, and effectiveness evaluations to ensure its efficiency and scalability.
The TC finances diagnostics, policy dialogues, and capacity building consistent with the Bank’s Environmental and Social Policy Framework (ESPF).

chunk_title: Budget, Executing Agency, and Execution Structure
text: Budget Finalize Evaluation Design US$12,000.00 US$12,000.00 Primary Data Collection and Capacity Building US$88,000.00 US$88,000.00 Total US$100,000.00 US$100,000.00 V. Executing Agency and Execution Structure 5.1 The IDB will be the executing agency of the TC. CSD/HUD will lead the execution in close coordination with the beneficiary. The unit with disbursement Responsibility will be CSC/CBR. 5.2 At the request of the beneficiary, the Bank, through the Housing and Urban Development Division (CSD/HUD), will serve as the executing agency of the TC. In accordance with Annex II of OP-619-4, Bank execution — requested by COHAPAR and the Government of Paraná — is justified by the limited institutional capacity to lead the design and implementation of a rigorous impact evaluation, as well as by the need to ensure methodological independence and technical consistency throughout the evaluation process.

Description of Activities and Outputs 3.1 Component I: Finalize Evaluation Design. This component will finalize the evaluation methodology, define implementation details, and ensure access to administrative data. Activities include mapping datasets, establishing data-sharing agreements, governance protocols, cleaning and linking data. Outputs: methodology report and data access plan.

chunk_title: Objective and Justification – Solid Waste, Innovation and Expected Benefits
text: Meanwhile, solid waste treatment—while high in terms of collection coverage—is affected by inadequate conditions for treatment and recycling, creating a risk of water pollution and increasing greenhouse gas emissions. In Mexico, 102,895.00 tons of urban waste are generated daily, of which 83.93% are collected and 78.54% are disposed of in final disposal sites, recycling only 9.63% of the waste generated. These services are legally under the jurisdiction of the municipal level; water and sanitation are usually managed by the same entity, while solid waste management has lacked attention and resources, contributing to the problem of inadequate solid waste disposal, including biosolids from wastewater treatment plants, worsening the pollution of surface and ground waters. With an increasing population and the growing effects of climate change, these challenges must be urgently addressed with insufficient time and resources; technological innovation can play a key role in providing more effective and faster solutions. Sector institutions in Mexico, such as the Ministry for the Environment and Natural Resources (SEMARNAT), National Water Commission (CONAGUA), National Association of Water and Sanitation Entities (ANEAS), also consider the role of innovation as crucial for the operators to be able to overcome these challenges. Newly appointed President, Claudia Sheinbaum, expressed her commitment to promoting innovation; among her key projects, the development of technological solutions for the efficient use of water and energy was included as part of a new technological development plan for Mexico. This technical cooperation can, thus, help setting up financing schemes and operations, by supporting the elaboration of such studies and pre-investment projects, duly considering Japanese innovation and state-of-the art expertise. The TC will directly benefit sectoral organizations related to water, sanitation, and solid waste, and indirectly benefit households and users of these services in Mexico. It is expected that the adoption and/or adaptation of innovative solutions (e.g., innovative management models, or technologies for loss reduction, etc.) will contribute to supporting the efforts of the countries in the region to achieve sectoral sustainable development goals, duly considering the potential impacts of climate change emergencies and natural disasters.

5.1 The Bank, through its Water and Sanitation Division (INE/WSA), in coordination with CSC/ACU, will serve as the executing entity for this TC. The Bank’s role as the Executing Agency is justified by its leadership in implementing the TCs from which the technical notes and knowledge products to be disseminated under this TC were developed. Insights will also support the development of new knowledge products on NbS in the water sector, climate adaptation and the WEF nexus approach.
